Protocol. We give the modified DKG protocol Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} from GJKR-DKG in FigureÂ 12. The participating parties can drop out, as long as Î·D+Î´D<1/3subscriptğœ‚ğ·subscriptğ›¿ğ·13\eta_{D}+\delta_{D}<1/3.

Correctness and security. We analyze the properties of Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} in this section. We start by revisiting the correctness and security definitions of GJKR-DKG, and then discuss how our definition differs from theirs because of a weakening of the communication model. In GJKR-DKG, correctness has three folds:

  1. 1.

    All subsets of honest parties define the same unique secret key.

  2. 2.

    All honest parties have the same public key.

  3. 3.

    The secret key is uniformly random.

Security means that no information about the secret key can be learned by the adversary except for what is implied by the public key. For Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}}, if the server is honest, then our communication model (Â§2.3) is equivalent to having a fully synchronous channel, hence in this case the correctness and security properties in the prior work hold. When the server is malicious, we show that Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} satisfies the following correctness (C1, C2, C3, C4) and security (S).

  • C1.

    Each honest party either has no secret at the end or agrees on the same QUAL with other honest parties.

  • C2.

    The agreed QUAL sets defines a unique secret key.

  • C3.

    The secret key defined by QUAL is uniformly random.

  • C4.

    Each honest party, either has no public key, or outputs the same public key with other honest parties.

  • S.

    Malicious parties learns no information about the secret key except for what is implied by the public key.

Lemma 2.

Let the participants in DKG be Lğ¿L parties and a server. If Î´D+Î·D<1/3subscriptğ›¿ğ·subscriptğœ‚ğ·13\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, then under the communication model defined in SectionÂ 2.2, protocol Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} (Fig.Â 12) has properties C1, C2, C3, C4 and S in the presence of a malicious adversary controlling the server and up to Î·Dsubscriptğœ‚ğ·\eta_{D} fraction of the parties.

Proof. Since L=3â€‹â„“+1ğ¿3â„“1L=3\ell+1, and by Î´D+Î·D<1/3subscriptğ›¿ğ·subscriptğœ‚ğ·13\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, at most â„“â„“\ell are malicious (the dropouts can be treated as malicious parties who do not send the prescribed messages). We first show under which cases the honest parties will have no share. Note that the parties that are excluded from ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2\mathcal{D}_{2} are those who are honest but did not receive a complaint against a malicious party who performed wrong sharing; and parties that are excluded from ğ’Ÿ3subscriptğ’Ÿ3\mathcal{D}_{3} are those who have complained at iğ‘–i in step (b) but did not receive shares from iğ‘–i at this step. If the server drops messages (sent from one online honest party to another) in the above two cases, then in the cross-check step, the honest parties will not receive more than 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 QUALs, and hence will abort. In this case, honest parties in the end has no share.

Now we prove C1 by contradiction. Suppose there are two honest parties P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} at the end of the protocol who holds secrets (not abort) and they have different QUAL. Then this means P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} received at least 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 same QUAL sets S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} and P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} received at least same 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 QUAL sets S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2}. W.l.o.g., assume that there are â„“âˆ’vâ„“ğ‘£\ell-v malicious parties (vâ‰¥Î“ğ‘£Î“v\geq 0). In the 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 sets S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1}, at least â„“+1+vâ„“1ğ‘£\ell+1+v of them are from honest parties. Similarly, for the 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 sets S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2}, at least â„“+1+vâ„“1ğ‘£\ell+1+v are from other honest parties different than above (since an honest party cannot send both S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2}). However, note that we have in total 2â€‹â„“+1+v2â„“1ğ‘£2\ell+1+v honest parties, which derives a contradiction.

Recall that at most â„“â„“\ell parties are malicious, so the QUAL set has at least â„“+1â„“1\ell+1 parties, and since we have C1, now C2 is guaranteed. Moreover, since QUAL contains at least one honest party, the secret key is uniform (C3). C4 follows exactly from the work GJKR. The proof for S is the same as GKJR, except that the simulator additionally simulates the agreement protocol in LemmaÂ 3.

Remark. An important difference between Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} and standard DKG protocols is that we allow aborts and allow honest parties to not have shares at the end of the protocol. When some honest parties do not have shares of the secret key, the server is still able to get sum (decryption still works) because malicious parties hold the shares.

B.3 Collection phase

The detailed protocol for each round in the collection phase is described in FigureÂ 13. At the beginning of round tğ‘¡t, the server notifies the clients who should be involved, namely Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t}. A client who gets a notification can download public keys of its neighbors Atâ€‹(i)subscriptğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘–A_{t}(i) from PKI server (the server should tell clients how to map client IDs to the names in PKI). To reduce the overall run time, clients can pre-fetch public keys used in the coming rounds.

Assume now each decryptor uâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¢ğ’Ÿu\in\mathcal{D} holds share susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} of Sâ€‹Kğ‘†ğ¾SK (i.e., there is a polynomial pğ‘p such that pâ€‹(u)=suğ‘ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢p(u)=s_{u} and pâ€‹(Î“)=Sâ€‹Kğ‘Î“ğ‘†ğ¾p(0)=SK). To transfer its share, each uâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¢ğ’Ÿu\in\mathcal{D} acts as a VSS dealer exactly the same as the first part in Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} (Fig.9) to share susubscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢s_{u} to new decryptor jâˆˆğ’Ÿnâ€‹eâ€‹wğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¤j\in\mathcal{D}_{new}. In detail, uğ‘¢u chooses a polynomial puâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p^{*}_{u} of degree â„“â„“\ell and sets puâˆ—â€‹(Î“)=susubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¢Î“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢p^{*}_{u}(0)=s_{u} and all other coefficients of puâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¢p^{*}_{u} to be random. Then, uğ‘¢u sends puâˆ—â€‹(j)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘—p^{*}_{u}(j) to each new decryptor jâˆˆğ’Ÿnâ€‹eâ€‹wğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¤j\in\mathcal{D}_{new}.

The new share of Sâ€‹Kğ‘†ğ¾SK held by jğ‘—j, sjâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—â€²s_{j}^{\prime}, is defined to be a linear combination of the received shares: sjâ€²:=âˆ‘uâˆˆğ’ŸÎ²uâ‹…puâˆ—â€‹(j)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘¢ğ’Ÿâ‹…subscriptğ›½ğ‘¢subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘—s_{j}^{\prime}:=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{D}}\beta_{u}\cdot p^{*}_{u}(j), where the combination coefficients {Î²u}uâˆˆğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ğ’Ÿ\{\beta_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{D}} are constants (given the set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, we can compute {Î²u}uâˆˆğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ›½ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ğ’Ÿ\{\beta_{u}\}_{u\in\mathcal{D}}). Note that the same issue about communication model for DKG also exists here, but the same relaxation applies.

Here we require that Î·D+Î´D<1/3subscriptğœ‚ğ·subscriptğ›¿ğ·13\eta_{D}+\delta_{D}<1/3 for both ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} and ğ’Ÿnâ€‹eâ€‹wsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘¤\mathcal{D}_{new}. For each receiving decryptor jâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ’Ÿj\in\mathcal{D}, it computes sjâ€²=âˆ‘uâˆˆğ’Ÿoâ€‹lâ€‹dÎ²uâ‹…su,jsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘‘â‹…subscriptğ›½ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘—s_{j}^{\prime}=\sum_{u\in\mathcal{D}_{old}}\beta_{u}\cdot s_{u,j}, where each Î²usubscriptğ›½ğ‘¢\beta_{u} is some fixed constant.

Since the sharing part is exactly the same as Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\text{DKG}} and the share combination happens locally, the same correctness and security argument of DKG applies. Specifically, for correctness, each honest party either has no secret at the end or agrees on the same QUAL with other honest parties; and the QUAL defines the unique same secret key before resharing. For security, a malicious adversary will not learn any information, but can cause the protocol aborts.

Appendix C Requirements on Parameters

C.1 The number of decryptors

In this section, we show how to choose Lğ¿L such that, given N,Î·,Î´Dğ‘ğœ‚subscriptğ›¿ğ·N,\eta,\delta_{D}, we can guarantee less than 1/3131/3 of the Lğ¿L chosen decryptors are malicious. Note that Î´Dsubscriptğ›¿ğ·\delta_{D} is given because this can be controlled by the server, i.e., the server can decide how long to wait for the decryptors to respond.

To guarantee 2â€‹Î´D+Î·D<1/32subscriptğ›¿ğ·subscriptğœ‚ğ·132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3 (TheoremÂ 3), a necessary condition is that Î·<1/3âˆ’2â€‹Î´Dğœ‚132subscriptğ›¿ğ·\eta<1/3-2\delta_{D}. Prâ¡[Xâ‰¥(Î·+(1/3âˆ’2â€‹Î´Dâˆ’Î·))â€‹L]â‰¤eâˆ’2â€‹Lâ€‹(1/3âˆ’Î·âˆ’2â€‹Î´D)2,Prğ‘‹ğœ‚132subscriptğ›¿ğ·ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘’2ğ¿superscript13ğœ‚2subscriptğ›¿ğ·2\Pr[X\geq(\eta+(1/3-2\delta_{D}-\eta))L]\leq e^{-2L(1/3-\eta-2\delta_{D})^{2}},

For Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î´Dsubscriptğ›¿ğ·\delta_{D} both being 1%, the choice of L=6â€‹Î“ğ¿6Î“L=60 (SectionÂ 6) gives 1â€‹Î“âˆ’61superscriptÎ“610^{-6} probability. If we double Lğ¿L to be 120, then this guarantees 1â€‹Î“âˆ’1â€‹21superscriptÎ“1210^{-12} probability.

C.2 Proof of LemmaÂ 1

The algorithm in FigureÂ 1 gives a random graph Gâ€‹(n,Ïµ)ğºğ‘›italic-ÏµG(n,\epsilon). Concretely, from GilbertÂ [35], let gâ€‹(n,Ïµ)ğ‘”ğ‘›italic-Ïµg(n,\epsilon) be the probability that graph Gâ€‹(n,Ïµ)ğºğ‘›italic-ÏµG(n,\epsilon) has disconnected components, and it can be recursively computed as

We numerically depict the above upper bound of the probability gâ€‹(n,Ïµ)ğ‘”ğ‘›italic-Ïµg(n,\epsilon) for different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in FigureÂ 14. Appendix D Security Proofs

D.1 Security definition

We say a protocol Î Î \Pi securely realizes ideal functionality â„±â„±\mathcal{F} in the presence of a malicious adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} if there exists a probabilistic polynomial time algorithm, or simulator, ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}, such that for any probabilistic polynomial time ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, the distribution of the output of the real-world execution of Î Î \Pi is (statistically or computationally) indistinguishable from the distribution of the output of the ideal-world execution invoking â„±â„±\mathcal{F}: the output of both worldsâ€™ execution includes the inputs and outputs of honest parties the view of the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. In our proof, we focus on the computational notion of security. Note that ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the ideal world has one-time access to â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, and has the inputs of the corrupted parties controlled by ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}.

D.2 Ideal functionalities

We provide ideal functionality for Flamingo in FigureÂ 4. Looking ahead in the proof, we also need to define an ideal functionality for the setup phase and an ideal functionality for a single round in the collection phase, which we give as FigureÂ 3 and FigureÂ 15.

We model the trusted source of initial randomness as a functionality â„±randsubscriptâ„±rand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}}; that is, a party or ideal functionality on calling â„±randsubscriptâ„±rand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}} will receive a uniform random value vğ‘£v in {Î“,1}Î»superscriptÎ“1ğœ†\{0,1\}^{\lambda}, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is the length of the PRG seed.

D.3 Proof of TheoremÂ 1

The ideal functionality â„±setupsubscriptâ„±setup\mathcal{F}_{\text{setup}} for the setup phase is defined in FigureÂ 3. Depending on whether the server is corrupted or not, we have the following two cases.

  1. 1.

    When the server is not corrupted, then the communication model is equivalent to a secure broadcast channel. By security of GJKR, Î setupsubscriptÎ setup\Pi_{\text{setup}} securely realizes â„±setupsubscriptâ„±setup\mathcal{F}_{\text{setup}}.

  2. 2.

    When the server is corrupted, we build a simulator for the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. We start by listing the messages that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} sees throughout the setup phase:

    • â€¢

      A random value vğ‘£v from â„±randsubscriptâ„±rand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}};

    • â€¢

      All the messages in Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}} that are sent via the server;

    • â€¢

      All the messages in Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}} that are seen by the corrupted decryptors.

    The simulator first calls â„±randsubscriptâ„±rand\mathcal{F}_{\text{rand}} and receives a value vğ‘£v. Then the simulator interacts with ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} acting as the honest decryptors. The simulator aborts if any honest decryptors would abort in Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}. There are two ways that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} can cheat: 1) ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} cheats in Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}, and in AppendixÂ B.2, we show the simulator can simulate the view of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}; 2) ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} cheats outside Î DKGsubscriptÎ DKG\Pi_{\textrm{DKG}}, this means ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} chooses a wrong set of decryptors, or it broadcasts wrong signatures. So the simulator aborts as long as it does not receive 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 valid signatures on Pâ€‹Kğ‘ƒğ¾PKs signed by the set defined by vğ‘£v.

Finally, note that our threat model (Â§2.3) assumes that the server is also controlled by the adversary, i.e., the first case is not needed here; but it will be useful when we analyze the robust version in AppendixÂ E.1.

D.4 Proof of TheoremÂ 2

The proof for dropout resilience is rather simple: in the setup phase, at most Î´Dsubscriptğ›¿ğ·\delta_{D} fraction of Lğ¿L selected decryptors drop out; then in one round of the collection phase, another Î´Dsubscriptğ›¿ğ·\delta_{D} fraction of decryptors can drop out. Since 2â€‹Î´D+Î·D<1/32subscriptğ›¿ğ·subscriptğœ‚ğ·132\delta_{D}+\eta_{D}<1/3, and 3â€‹â„“+1=L3â„“1ğ¿3\ell+1=L (Fig.Â 12), the online decryptors can always help the server to reconstruct the secrets.

Lemma 3.

Assume there exists a PKI and a secure signature scheme; there are 3â€‹â„“+13â„“13\ell+1 parties with at most â„“â„“\ell colluding malicious parties. Each party has an input bit of 0 or 1 from a server. Then there exists a one-round protocol for honest parties to decide if the server sent the same value to all the honest parties.

Proof.

If an honest party receives 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 or more messages with the same value, then it means the server sends to all honest parties the same value. If an honest party receives less than 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 messages with the same value, it will abort; in this case the server must have sent different messages to different honest parties. âˆ

Remark. The above analysis of the agreement protocol shows where the threshold 1/3131/3 comes from. Consider the case where the threshold is 1/2 and 2â€‹â„“+1=L2â„“1ğ¿2\ell+1=L. For a target client, the (malicious) server can tell â„“/2â„“2\ell/2 decryptors that the client is online and tell another â„“/2+1â„“21\ell/2+1 decryptors that the client is offline. Then combined with the â„“â„“\ell malicious decryptorsâ€™ shares, the server has â„“/2+â„“â„“2â„“\ell/2+\ell shares to reconstruct individual mask, and â„“/2+1+â„“â„“21â„“\ell/2+1+\ell shares to reeconstruct the pairwise mask.

Now we analyze the per-round pairwise masks. Let the distribution of the view of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} in round tğ‘¡t be Î”tsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡\Delta_{t}. Appendix E Extension for Robustness

E.1 Robust protocol

As discussed in SectionÂ 9, we want the protocol to additionally guarantee robustness when the server is honest. FigureÂ 16 gives the abstraction of robustness. Specifically, our robust version Î sum-robustsubscriptÎ sum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}} has two key properties different from Î sumsubscriptÎ sum\Pi_{\text{sum}}: (1) client inputs are fixed after submitting their vectors in the report step; (i.e., malicious decryptors have no way to change the client inputs); (2) when the server is honest, the malicious clients cannot cause the protocol to abort, and the protocol will always output a sum of inputs from online clients. We treat clients who misbehave in the report step as equivalent to changing their inputs. We emphasize that this type of robustness is weaker than the robustness notion in other worksÂ [24, 50], and is practically meaningful only if correct computation in the report step and input validation are ensured.

We now describe two key changes to Î sumsubscriptÎ sum\Pi_{\text{sum}} that together bring robustness. The full description of Î sum-robustsubscriptÎ sum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}} is given as FigureÂ 18, where we highlight the changes from Î sumsubscriptÎ sum\Pi_{\text{sum}} in FigureÂ 13.

Using public-key encryption for both types of seeds. Instead of using symmetric encryption for the shares of mi,tsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘¡m_{i,t}, each client encrypts mi,tsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘¡m_{i,t} directly (but not the shares) using ElGamal encryption. This reduces the number of ciphertexts appended to the masked vector compared to Î sumsubscriptÎ sum\Pi_{\text{sum}}; but more importantly, later we will see how it combines with another technique (zero-knowledge proof for discrete log) to bring robustness. See the details in the report step of FigureÂ 18. This change in the report step will bring a change in the reconstruction step that the decryptors do threshold decryption on ciphertext mi,tsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘¡m_{i,t}, instead of decrypting the shares of mi,tsubscriptğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘¡m_{i,t} using symmetric keys.

Zero-knowledge proof in decryption. In the reconstruction step, in addition to decrypting, each decryptor uğ‘¢u, for each ciphertext (cÎ“,c1)subscriptğ‘Î“subscriptğ‘1(c_{0},c_{1}), proves to the server that logcÎ“(cÎ“)su=logggsu\log_{c_{0}}(c_{0})^{s_{u}}=\log_{g}g^{s_{u}}, where gsusuperscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢g^{s_{u}} is known to the server. Note that gsusuperscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢g^{s_{u}} can be generated in the DKG along the way in the setup phase and stored by the server.

To prove that logcÎ“(cÎ“)su=logggsu\log_{c_{0}}(c_{0})^{s_{u}}=\log_{g}g^{s_{u}}, each decryptor chooses a random Î²âˆˆâ„¤qğ›½subscriptâ„¤ğ‘\beta\in\mathbb{Z}_{q} and sends to the server cÎ“Î²,gÎ²superscriptsubscriptğ‘Î“ğ›½superscriptğ‘”ğ›½c_{0}^{\beta},g^{\beta}. The server then sends to the decryptor a challenge eâˆˆâ„¤qğ‘’subscriptâ„¤ğ‘e\in\mathbb{Z}_{q}. The decryptor computes z=suâ‹…e+Î²ğ‘§â‹…subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘’ğ›½z=s_{u}\cdot e+\beta and sends zğ‘§z to the server. The sever checks that (cÎ“su)eâ‹…(cÎ“)Î²=cÎ“zâ‹…superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Î“subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘’superscriptsubscriptğ‘Î“ğ›½superscriptsubscriptğ‘Î“ğ‘§(c_{0}^{s_{u}})^{e}\cdot(c_{0})^{\beta}=c_{0}^{z} and (gsu)eâ‹…gÎ²=gzâ‹…superscriptsuperscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘ ğ‘¢ğ‘’superscriptğ‘”ğ›½superscriptğ‘”ğ‘§(g^{s_{u}})^{e}\cdot g^{\beta}=g^{z}. We use Fiat-Shamir transform to make the proof non-interactive.

Due to this proof of decryption, the server can exclude bogus partial decryptions from malicious decryptors; since the sharing polynomial for secret key sğ‘ s is of degree â„“â„“\ell and there are at least 2â€‹â„“+12â„“12\ell+1 honest online decryptors, the server is always able to reconstruct the result.

E.2 Proof of the robust protocol

Let Î¨TsubscriptÎ¨ğ‘‡\Psi_{T} be the sequential execution of Î setupsubscriptÎ setup\Pi_{\text{setup}} (Fig.11) and the Tğ‘‡T-round Î sum-robustsubscriptÎ sum-robust\Pi_{\text{sum-robust}}.

Theorem 4 (Security of Flamingo extension).

Let the security parameter be Îºğœ…\kappa. Let Î´,Î´D,Î·,Î·Dğ›¿subscriptğ›¿ğ·ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ·\delta,\delta_{D},\eta,\eta_{D} be threat model parameters as defined (Â§5.1,Â§5.2). Proof.

We present our proof for the two cases: the server is corrupted by ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} or the server is honest.

When the server is corrupted. When the server is corrupted, we aim to show that the protocol can securely realize â„±sum(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„±sumğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} in the (b) case. Now ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} corrupts a set of clients (as the above case) and the server. The construction of simulator ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the ideal world and the following hyrbid arguments is the same as AppendixÂ D.5.

When the server is not corrupted. We construct a simulator ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the ideal world that runs ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} as a subroutine.

  1. 1.

    ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} obtains ztsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡z_{t} from â„±sum-robust(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„±sum-robustğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum-robust}}^{(t)} (Fig.17).

  2. 2.

    ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} received a set ğ’ªtsubscriptğ’ªğ‘¡\mathcal{O}_{t} from â„›dropsubscriptâ„›drop\mathcal{R}_{\text{drop}} (see AppendixÂ D.5).

  3. 3.

    (Report step) ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} computes offline/online labels from the set ğ’ªtsubscriptğ’ªğ‘¡\mathcal{O}_{t}, and interact with ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} acting as the server. Here the collected masked inputs are all zeros and the seeds for the masks are generated by ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} itself.

  4. 4.

    (Cross-check step) ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} acts as honest decryptors in the cross-check step, and if all the honest decryptors would abort in the protocol prescription then ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} outputs whatever ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} outputs, and sends abort to â„±sum(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„±sumğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum}}^{(t)} and halts.

  5. 5.

    (Reconstruction step) ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} acts as the server in the reconstruction step, if the server would abort in the protocol prescription, then ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} outputs whatever ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} outputs, and sends abort to â„±sum-robust(t)superscriptsubscriptâ„±sum-robustğ‘¡\mathcal{F}_{\text{sum-robust}}^{(t)} and halts.

We construct a series of hybrid execution, starting from the real world to the ideal world execution.

Comparison with BBGLR. When the server is honest, both BBGLR and Flamingo (without robustness) has no guaranteed output delivery; a malicious server in BBGLR can learn several subsets of sum (Â§2.3), while in Flamingo a malicious server learns a single sum from at least 1âˆ’Î·âˆ’Î´1ğœ‚ğ›¿1-\eta-\delta fraction of clients (Â§5, Fig.4). The robust version of Flamingo improves over Flamingo in the honest-server case: the output delivery is guaranteed (Â§E.2).

Another difference is the selection of clients per round, which is orthogonal to the single-round protocol design. A malicious server may select a set of clients (Stsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S_{t}) with many being malicious, and this violates the parameter constraints on Î·ğœ‚\eta in BBGLR, and hence the server will learn the sum of inputs from a small number of honest clients; in contrast, in this setting, the server in Flamingo will obtain a random vector. However, the tradeoff (Â§10) is that BBGLR tolerates adaptive adversaries across rounds but Flamingo does not.
